By capturing the growth trajectories of multiple processes within the same model, researchers can examine how changes in one variable are associated with changes in another, providing insights into the dynamic interplay between developmental processes."}]},{"type":"element","tag":"p","props":{},"children":[{"type":"text","value":"In these models, each variable has its own set of latent growth factors‚Äîtypically intercepts and slopes‚Äîthat represent initial status and rates of change. By allowing the latent factors of different variables to correlate, multivariate LGCMs assess the extent to which the trajectories of the variables are related. This approach enables the investigation of questions such as whether individuals who start higher on one variable also start higher on another, or whether the rate of change in one variable predicts the rate of change in another. Multivariate LGCMs are particularly useful in fields like psychology, education, and health sciences, where multiple developmental processes may influence each other over time. For example, researchers might use these models to explore the relationship between academic achievement and self-esteem during adolescence, assessing how changes in one domain affect changes in the other. By capturing the shared and unique aspects of growth in different variables, multivariate LGCMs offer a comprehensive view of longitudinal data."}]},{"type":"element","tag":"div","props":{"className":["when-to-use-section"]},"children":[{"type":"element","tag":"h3","props":{"id":"when-to-use-multivariate-latent-growth-curve-models"},"children":[{"type":"text","value":"ü§î When to Use Multivariate Latent Growth Curve Models?"}]},{"type":"element","tag":"p","props":{},"children":[{"type":"text","value":"MLGCMs are useful when:"}]},{"type":"element","tag":"ol","props":{},"children":[{"type":"element","tag":"li","props":{},"children":[{"type":"text","value":"You have more than one outcome variable measured repeatedly over time."}]},{"type":"element","tag":"li","props":{},"children":[{"type":"text","value":"You want to understand how growth trajectories of different variables are related."}]},{"type":"element","tag":"li","props":{},"children":[{"type":"text","value":"You need to examine both individual and shared dynamics in longitudinal data."}]}]}]},{"type":"element","tag":"div","props":{"className":["getting-started-section"]},"children":[{"type":"element","tag":"h3","props":{"id":"getting-started-with-multivariate-latent-growth-curve-models"},"children":[{"type":"text","value":"üöÄ Getting Started with Multivariate Latent Growth Curve Models"}]},{"type":"element","tag":"p","props":{},"children":[{"type":"text","value":"In this tutorial, we will guide you through fitting an MLGCM using R.
